ny: Kutsutsana ndi Israeli ndi chikhulupiriro cha Iran, chomwe chimathandizira magulu ankhondo achisilamu aku Palestine ndi Lebanon omwe amatsutsana ndi mtendere ndi Israeli, zomwe Tehran sazizindikira.

en: "What has happened in Palestine in recent years annuls all plans for compromise with the Zionist enemy (Israel) because no plan for Palestine can be implemented in the absence or contrary to the opinions of its owners, the Palestinians," Khamenei said, speaking in Arabic and addressing Palestinians and other Arabs.
ny: "Zomwe zachitika ku Palestine m'zaka zaposachedwa zimathetsa mapulani onse ogwirizana ndi mdani wa Zionist (Israel) chifukwa palibe dongosolo la Palestine lomwe lingathe kukhazikitsidwa pakalibe kapena mosiyana ndi malingaliro a eni ake, Palestina," adatero Khamenei, polankhula. Chiarabu komanso kulankhula ndi ma Palestine ndi ma Arabu ena.

en: Thus, Khamenei said, all previous peace agreements -- such as the 1993 Oslo Accords, the two-state solution to resolve the Israeli-Palestinian conflict, and former U.S. President Donald Trump's plan dubbed the Deal of the Century "are null and void".
ny: Chifukwa chake, Khamenei adati, mapangano onse am'mbuyomu amtendere - monga 1993 Oslo Accords, njira yamayiko awiri yothetsa mkangano wa Israeli ndi Palestine, komanso dongosolo la Purezidenti wakale wa US a Donald Trump lotchedwa Deal of the Century "ndi zopanda pake". .

en: President Ebrahim Raisi, Irans military commanders and senior officials also attended the rallies in which people were allowed to march through the streets, the first time since the outbreak of the coronavirus pandemic two years ago.
ny: Purezidenti Ebrahim Raisi, akuluakulu ankhondo aku Iran ndi akuluakulu aboma nawonso adachita nawo misonkhano yomwe anthu amaloledwa kuguba m'misewu, koyamba kuyambira mliri wa coronavirus wayamba zaka ziwiri zapitazo.

en: Iran's Jerusalem Day rallies are held annually in support of Palestinians, who want East Jerusalem as the capital of a future state in territories captured by Israel in a 1967 war, on the last Friday of the Muslim fasting month of Ramadan.
ny: Misonkhano ya Iran ya Jerusalem Day imachitika chaka chilichonse pothandizira anthu aku Palestine, omwe akufuna kuti East Jerusalem akhale likulu la dziko lamtsogolo lomwe lidagwidwa ndi Israeli pankhondo ya 1967, Lachisanu lomaliza la mwezi wosala kudya wachisilamu wa Ramadan.

en: "Stop your vicious deeds. You know well that we are people of action and reaction," Revolutionary Guards commander Hossein Salami, addressing Israel, told demonstrators in Tehran.
ny: "Lekani zochita zanu zoipa. Mukudziwa bwino kuti ndife anthu ochitapo kanthu," mkulu wa asilikali a Revolutionary Guards Hossein Salami, polankhula ndi Israeli, adauza owonetsa ku Tehran.

en: "Our responses are painful. You create conditions for your own destruction. We will not leave you alone ...You know better than me what will befall you if you take evil action."
ny: "Mayankho athu ndi opweteka. Mumadzipangira zinthu zodziwonongera nokha. Sitidzakusiyani nokha ... Inu mukudziwa bwino kuposa ine zomwe zidzakupezeni ngati mutachita zoipa."

en: Iran's military has vowed to retaliate harshly against any attack by Israel, which has often voiced concern over the Iranian nuclear program. Tehran says the program is for peaceful purposes only.
ny: Asilikali aku Iran alonjeza kuti adzabwezera mwankhanza chilichonse chomwe Israeli adachita, zomwe nthawi zambiri zakhala zikuwonetsa kukhudzidwa ndi pulogalamu yanyukiliya ya Iran. Tehran akuti pulogalamuyi ndi yamtendere yokha.

en: Israel, whose existence the Islamic Republic does not recognize, has long threatened military action against Iran if talks between Tehran and world powers fail to curb Iranian nuclear activity. Iran says its nuclear ambitions are peaceful.
ny: Israel, yomwe dziko la Islamic Republic silikuzindikira, idawopseza kwanthawi yayitali kuti achitepo kanthu pankhondo motsutsana ndi Iran ngati zokambirana pakati pa Tehran ndi maulamuliro apadziko lonse lapansi zikulephera kuthetsa ntchito zanyukiliya za Iran. Iran yati zokhumba zake za nyukiliya ndi zamtendere.

en: In February, the Islamic Republic unveiled its "Kheibar Buster" missile with a range of 1,450 km (900 miles).
ny: Mu February, Islamic Republic idavumbulutsa mzinga wake wa "Kheibar Buster" wokhala ndi ma 1,450 km (900 miles).

en: Iran, which has one of the biggest missile programs in the Middle East, says its ballistic missiles have a range of up to 2,000 km (1,200 miles) and are capable of reaching its arch-foe Israel and U.S. bases in the region.
ny: Iran, yomwe ili ndi imodzi mwazinthu zazikulu kwambiri zoponya zida ku Middle East, yati zida zake zoponya zophonya zili ndi utali wa makilomita 2,000 (makilomita 1,200) ndipo zimatha kufikira adani ake akuluakulu a Israel ndi US mderali.

en: Kheibar refers to an ancient Jewish oasis in the Arabian Peninsula's Hijaz region that was overrun by Muslim warriors in the 7th century.
ny: Kheibar amatanthauza malo akale achiyuda kudera la Hijaz ku Arabia Peninsula komwe kudalandidwa ndi asitikali achisilamu m'zaka za zana lachisanu ndi chiwiri.

en: Tehran regards its ballistic missile program as an important deterrent against the United States, Israel and other adversaries, and has rejected Western demands to halt it.
ny: Tehran amawona pulogalamu yake yoponya mizinga ngati njira yofunika yolepheretsa United States, Israel ndi adani ena, ndipo yakana zomwe azungu akufuna kuti ayimitse.

en: Over the past year, Iran and the United States have engaged in fitful, indirect talks in Vienna to revive a 2015 nuclear deal that then-President Donald Trump reneged on in 2018 and that Iran, in turn, began violating in 2019.
ny: Chaka chatha, Iran ndi United States zakhala zikuchita zokambirana zoyenera, zosalunjika ku Vienna kuti zitsitsimutse mgwirizano wa nyukiliya wa 2015 womwe Purezidenti Donald Trump adaukana mu 2018 komanso kuti Iran idayamba kuphwanya mu 2019.

en: Under the 2015 deal, Iran agreed to limit its nuclear program in return for relief from economic sanctions.
ny: Pansi pa mgwirizano wa 2015, Iran idavomera kuchepetsa pulogalamu yake ya nyukiliya kuti ilandire mpumulo pazachuma.

en: While they appeared close to resurrecting the deal in March, talks stalled over last-minute Russian demands and whether Washington might drop Iran's Revolutionary Guards from its Foreign Terrorist Organization list.
ny: Ngakhale akuwoneka kuti atsala pang'ono kuukitsa mgwirizanowo mu Marichi, zokambirana zidayimilira pazofuna zaku Russia zomwe zatsala pang'ono kutha komanso ngati Washington ikhoza kusiya gulu la Iran la Revolutionary Guards pamndandanda wake wa Foreign Terrorist Organisation.

en: As Fewer Americans Attend Church, Can Coffee Shops Fill the Void?
ny: Monga Achimereka Ochepa Akupita Ku Tchalitchi, Kodi Malo Ogulitsa Khofi Angadzaze Chosowacho?

en: Churches and other houses of worship have historically played critical social and political functions in American society. But fewer people are attending religious services, and the decline of churches and other houses of worship threatens to leave a void that could potentially be filled by coffee shops.
ny: Mipingo ndi nyumba zina zolambirira zakhala zikugwira ntchito zofunika kwambiri pazandale komanso zandale ku America. Koma ndi anthu ochepa amene amapita ku mapemphero achipembedzo, ndipo kuchepa kwa matchalitchi ndi nyumba zina zopemphereramo kukuwopseza kuti pakhoza kukhala malo omwe masitolo ogulitsa khofi angathetse.

en: "For so much of American history, the church has really been — or their congregations have really been — essential, providing an unheralded role in providing cohesion and connectedness in communities … encouraging civic engagement and political participation," says Daniel Cox, director of the Survey Center on American Life and a senior fellow at the American Enterprise Institute.
ny: "M'mbiri yambiri ya ku America, tchalitchi chakhaladi - kapena mipingo yawo yakhala - yofunikira, kupereka gawo losavomerezeka popereka mgwirizano ndi mgwirizano pakati pa anthu ... Survey Center on American Life ndi mnzake wamkulu ku American Enterprise Institute.

en: "It was not happenstance or luck that the civil rights movement emerged out of the church," Cox says.
ny: "Sizinali zongochitika kapena mwayi kuti gulu lomenyera ufulu wachibadwidwe linatuluka mutchalitchi," akutero Cox.

en: "And you see that cross-culturally … whether it's in predominantly white rural communities, in the suburbs, wherever, churches have historically been really, really important."
ny: "Ndipo mukuwona kuti zikhalidwe zosiyanasiyana ... kaya ndi m'madera akumidzi ambiri azungu, m'midzi, kulikonse kumene, mipingo inali yofunika kwambiri m'mbiri yakale."

en: Churches and other houses of worship have also played a role in helping immigrants assimilate once they arrive in America, Cox says.
ny: Mipingo ndi nyumba zina zolambirira zathandizanso anthu osamukira kumayiko ena kuti atengerepo akafika ku America, akutero Cox.

en: In 1999, 70% of Americans said they belonged to a church, mosque or synagogue.
ny: Mu 1999, anthu 70 pa 100 alionse aku America adanena kuti ndi a tchalitchi, mzikiti kapena sunagoge.

en: By 2020, that number had dropped to 47%. A 2019 survey found that only about three in 10 Americans say they attend weekly religious services.
ny: Pofika 2020, chiwerengerochi chidatsika mpaka 47%. Kafukufuku wa 2019 adapeza kuti ndi anthu atatu okha mwa 10 aku America omwe amati amapita kuchipembedzo sabata iliyonse.

en: Third places  Lack of involvement and affiliation with churches, mosques and synagogues means people might be missing out on what urban sociologist Ray Oldenburg dubbed as "third places" — public gathering spots that offer something that home, the "first place," and work, the "second place," might not.
ny: Malo achitatu Kupanda kutengapo mbali komanso kugwirizana ndi mipingo, mizikiti ndi masunagoge kumatanthauza kuti anthu atha kuphonya zomwe katswiri wa zachikhalidwe cha anthu akumatauni Ray Oldenburg adazitcha "malo achitatu" - malo osonkhanira anthu omwe amapereka chinthu chomwe kunyumba, "malo oyamba," ndi ntchito, “malo achiwiri,” mwina sangatero.

en: Oldenburg argued that third places are critical to a communitys social vitality.
ny: Oldenburg ananena kuti malo achitatu ndi ofunika kwambiri pa moyo wa anthu ammudzi.

en: An October 2021 survey conducted by the American Survey Center found that commercial spaces like coffee houses foster trust and connection in American communities and could help fill the void left by churches.
ny: Kafukufuku wa Okutobala 2021 wopangidwa ndi American Survey Center adapeza kuti malo ogulitsa ngati nyumba za khofi amalimbikitsa kukhulupirirana ndi kulumikizana pakati pa anthu aku America ndipo atha kuthandiza kudzaza mipingo yosiyidwa.

en: "If you're a regular at a cafe, the barista may know what you usually order, and they can make it for you, and that feels good," says clinical psychologist Dr. Maria Espinola, an assistant professor in the Department of Psychiatry and Behavioral Neuroscience at the University of Cincinnati College of Medicine.
ny: Dr. Maria Espinola, katswiri wa zamaganizo Dr. Maria Espinola, yemwe ndi pulofesa wothandizira ku Dipatimenti ya Psychiatry anati: ndi Behavioral Neuroscience ku University of Cincinnati College of Medicine.

en: "It feels good to be recognized, to know that people are expecting you, to know that people care about you, to know that you belong, because the need for belonging and human connection is a fundamental need that we all have, and it's important to have that fulfilled in different ways," Espinola says.
ny: "Ndimamva bwino kuzindikiridwa, kudziwa kuti anthu akukuyembekezerani, kudziwa kuti anthu amakukondani, kudziwa kuti ndinu munthu, chifukwa kufunikira kokhala nawo limodzi ndi kulumikizana ndi anthu ndizofunikira zomwe tonsefe tili nazo, ndipo ndikofunikira. kuti izi zikwaniritsidwe m'njira zosiyanasiyana," akutero Espinola.

en: "So, places like third places can allow us to do that."
ny: "Choncho, malo ngati malo achitatu angatilole kuchita zimenezo."

en: In the past, churches and other houses of worship have been a third place for many Americans.
ny: Kale, matchalitchi ndi nyumba zina zolambirira zakhala malo achitatu kwa anthu ambiri aku America.

en: In 2019, 67% of people surveyed said they have a third place — a coffee shop, bar, restaurant, park or other place in their community that they visit regularly.
ny: Mu 2019, 67% ya anthu omwe adafunsidwa adati ali ndi malo achitatu - malo ogulitsira khofi, malo odyera, malo odyera, paki kapena malo ena amdera lawo omwe amapitako pafupipafupi.

en: That number dropped to 56% in 2021 — a number that could have been affected by the COVID-19 pandemic.
ny: Chiwerengerochi chatsika mpaka 56% mu 2021 - chiwerengero chomwe chikadakhudzidwa ndi mliri wa COVID-19.

en: "What we found was that people who had a third place were much more connected to their community," says Cox. "They're much more likely to engage in other activities there.
ny: "Zomwe tidapeza ndikuti anthu omwe anali ndi malo achitatu anali olumikizana kwambiri ndi anthu amdera lawo," akutero Cox. "Amakhala ndi mwayi wochita zinthu zina kumeneko.

en: They are much more trusting of their neighbors. There's a whole great array of positive social outcomes that were connected to having a third place … and for a lot of Americans, it's a coffee shop or a cafe."
ny: Amakhulupirira kwambiri anansi awo. Pali zotsatira zabwino zambiri zomwe zidalumikizidwa ndikukhala ndi malo achitatu ... ndipo kwa anthu aku America ambiri, ndi malo ogulitsira khofi kapena malo odyera."

en: What coffee shops have in their favor is that they can be found almost everywhere, all over the country, and anyone who wants to can stop by regularly.
ny: Chomwe masitolo ogulitsa khofi amawakomera ndichakuti amapezeka pafupifupi kulikonse, m'dziko lonselo, ndipo aliyense amene akufuna atha kuyima pafupipafupi.

en: And many are open most days of the week.
ny: Ndipo ambiri amatsegula masiku ambiri a sabata.

en: Cox says even brief coffee shop encounters can increase a sense of belonging.
ny: Cox akuti ngakhale kukumana kwakanthawi kogulitsa khofi kumatha kukulitsa chidwi.

en: "I think there's a lot of potential here, and a lot of it is unrealized potential," Cox says.
ny: "Ndikuganiza kuti pali zambiri zomwe zingatheke pano, ndipo zambiri sizingatheke," akutero Cox.

en: "But in terms of what they could do, there's a lot there.
ny: "Koma malinga ndi zomwe angachite, pali zambiri pamenepo.

en: I've been in places where the same group of folks come in there to play chess.
ny: Ndakhala m'malo omwe gulu lomwelo la anthu limabwera kudzasewera chess.

en: Or they have their informal bunch of retirees. … They just got together, and they talked and chatted and caught up with each other. … I don't know where else they would have gone — maybe a church, but maybe not — to share information, to encourage each other to maybe get involved in an activity.
ny: Kapena ali ndi gulu lawo lopuma pantchito. … Iwo anangosonkhana pamodzi, ndipo anacheza ndi kucheza ndi kugwirana wina ndi mzake. …Sindikudziwa kuti akadapita kuti—mwina mpingo, koma mwina ayi—kugawana zambiri, kulimbikitsana kuti mwina kutenga nawo mbali muzochitika zina.

en: And I think that is what is so powerful about coffee shops."
ny: Ndipo ndikuganiza kuti ndizomwe zili zamphamvu kwambiri pamashopu a khofi. "

en: What US Mayors Are Most Worried About After the Pandemic
ny: Zomwe Meya aku US Akuda nkhawa Kwambiri Pambuyo pa Mliri

en: Americas mayors are most concerned about the lingering mental health effects of the COVID-19 pandemic, according to a nationwide survey of 126 mayors conducted during the summer of 2021.
ny: Mameya aku America akuda nkhawa kwambiri ndi zomwe zachitika chifukwa cha mliri wa COVID-19, malinga ndi kafukufuku wapadziko lonse wa ameya 126 omwe adachitika nthawi yachilimwe cha 2021.

en: The respondents headed cities with at least 75,000 residents. The local leaders are still focused on traditional issues such as violent crime, the economy and infrastructure, but they are most concerned about the pandemics long-term impact on the mental health of their constituents.
ny: Ofunsidwawo adatsogolera mizinda yokhala ndi anthu osachepera 75,000. Atsogoleri amderali amayang'anabe pazachikhalidwe monga zachiwawa, zachuma komanso zomangamanga, koma akuda nkhawa kwambiri ndi miliri yomwe yakhala ikukhudza nthawi yayitali pamaganizidwe a anthu omwe amawazungulira.

en: Mental health was top of mind for Michael Udine when he was sworn in as mayor of Broward County, Florida, in November 2021.
ny: Thanzi lamalingaliro linali lopambana kwa Michael Udine pomwe adalumbiritsidwa kukhala meya wa Broward County, Florida, mu Novembala 2021.

en: "Everything that was a potential issue pre-pandemic has pretty much been exacerbated by the pandemic," he says. "There were issues going into the pandemic, and it was becoming more and more important on everyone's radar screen about the mental health of people of all ages. And I think the pandemic pretty much supercharged those issues."
ny: "Chilichonse chomwe chingakhale vuto lomwe lisanachitike mliri wakula kwambiri chifukwa cha mliri," akutero. "Panali zovuta zomwe zidayamba kuchitika mliriwu, ndipo udayamba kukhala wofunikira kwambiri pazithunzi za radar ya aliyense wokhudza thanzi lamalingaliro a anthu azaka zonse.

en: It is not unusual for large outbreaks of disease to have a negative impact on mental health, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, which reports that rates of anxiety and depressive disorders among adults increased during the pandemic.
ny: Si zachilendo kuti miliri yayikulu iwononge thanzi lamaganizidwe, malinga ndi Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, yomwe inanena kuti ziwopsezo za nkhawa ndi kukhumudwa pakati pa akuluakulu zidakwera panthawi ya mliri.

en: The pandemic has also adversely influenced the emotional and mental health of about one-third of Americas youth.
ny: Mliriwu wakhudzanso kwambiri thanzi ndi malingaliro a achinyamata pafupifupi gawo limodzi mwa magawo atatu a achinyamata aku America.

en: "What we've seen is just such anxiety, kids who wouldn't ordinarily have a meltdown, because it's so much change and difficulty adjusting to transitions," Maryland psychologist Mary Karapetian Alvord told VOA last month. "We've also seen a lot more sadness and depression."
ny: "Zomwe taziwona ndi nkhawa zotere, ana omwe sangakhale ndi vuto, chifukwa ndikusintha kwakukulu komanso zovuta kusintha kusintha," katswiri wa zamaganizo ku Maryland Mary Karapetian Alvord adauza VOA mwezi watha. "Tawonanso zambiri zachisoni ndi kupsinjika maganizo."

en: Early on in the pandemic, mayors were more focused on city operations, budget shortfalls and the threat the pandemic posed to small businesses, according to David Glick, an associate professor of political science at Boston University and a co-author of the 2021 Menino Survey of Mayors.
ny: Kumayambiriro kwa mliriwu, ameya adangoyang'ana kwambiri ntchito zamatawuni, kuchepa kwa bajeti komanso chiwopsezo chomwe chimayambitsa mabizinesi ang'onoang'ono, malinga ndi a David Glick, pulofesa wothandizira pazandale ku yunivesite ya Boston komanso wolemba nawo kafukufuku wa 2021 Menino Survey. a Mameya.

en: "Some of those concerns still remain, but what we saw more of in 2021 … is concern about some of the long-term impacts on individual residents," Glick says. "Concerns about polarization over vaccines and just people being pushed to their limits … and certainly less on their city budgets and revenues and having to cut programs and some of those types of things that were probably more top of mind earlier in the pandemic."
ny: "Zina mwazodetsa zidakalipo, koma zomwe tidaziwona mu 2021 ... ndikukhudzidwa ndi zovuta zina zomwe zingakhudze anthu okhalamo," akutero Glick. "Nkhawa zakugawikana kwa katemera komanso anthu akungokakamizidwa ...

en: Over half of mayors, 52%, are worried about "lingering mental health challenges and trauma," according to the survey. Additionally, more than one-third of mayors, 37%, are worried about learning loss among young people.
ny: Opitilira theka la mameya, 52%, ali ndi nkhawa "zovuta zamaganizidwe komanso kuvulala," malinga ndi kafukufukuyu. Kuphatikiza apo, opitilira gawo limodzi mwa magawo atatu a mameya, 37%, ali ndi nkhawa zakutaya kuphunzira pakati pa achinyamata.

en: "Second only to mental health and trauma, and they're probably not totally independent concerns," Glick says. "It is part of that shift of mayors concerns from immediate threats to businesses closing and people getting sick, to some of these longer-term consequences that are going to persist in the future. And learning loss among their students, theyre worried it's going to persist for many, many, many years into the future. It's hard to make up for."
ny: "Chachiwiri ku thanzi laubongo komanso kuvulala, ndipo mwina sizongodziyimira pawokha," akutero Glick. "Ndi gawo limodzi la kusintha kwa mameya omwe akukhudzidwa ndi zomwe zikuwopseza kutsekedwa kwa mabizinesi ndi anthu kudwala, kupita ku zina mwazotsatira zanthawi yayitali zomwe zipitilira mtsogolo. kupitirirabe kwa zaka zambiri, zambiri, zambiri zamtsogolo.

en: According to the survey, other top concerns for Americas mayors include the financial insecurity of low-income residents (33%), the closing of small businesses (29%) and increased crime and violence (26%).
ny: Malinga ndi kafukufukuyu, nkhawa zina zazikulu za ameya aku America ndizovuta zachuma za anthu omwe amapeza ndalama zochepa (33%), kutsekedwa kwa mabizinesi ang'onoang'ono (29%) komanso kuchuluka kwa umbanda ndi ziwawa (26%).

en: Just 7% of mayors are worried about the shift to remote work and the long-term impact that could have on outmigration — people moving away from their cities.
ny: 7% yokha ya ameya ali ndi nkhawa ndi kusamuka kupita ku ntchito zakutali komanso kukhudzidwa kwanthawi yayitali komwe kungakhudze kusamuka - anthu akuchoka m'mizinda yawo.

en: The $350 billion in funding from the American Rescue Plan to local and state governments could help mayors address some of their concerns. The survey found that 78% of mayors believe the money will allow them to make meaningful change.
ny: Ndalama zokwana madola 350 biliyoni zochokera ku American Rescue Plan kupita ku maboma am'deralo ndi maboma zitha kuthandiza mameya kuthana ndi nkhawa zawo. Kafukufukuyu adapeza kuti 78% ya ma meya amakhulupirira kuti ndalamazi ziwathandiza kuti asinthe.

en: "What we're seeing is a large majority are using it for things they consider to be transformative and will make major changes to their cities," Glick says, "instead of feeling obligated or feeling the necessity to use it to plug up over-budget gaps to keep the doors open and the lights on."
ny: "Zomwe tikuwona ndizakuti ambiri akuzigwiritsa ntchito pazinthu zomwe amaziwona kuti zikusintha ndipo asintha kwambiri mizinda yawo," akutero Glick, "m'malo modzimva kuti ali ndi udindo kapena kufunikira koigwiritsa ntchito kuti ayimitse. mipata ya bajeti kuti zitseko zitseguke komanso magetsi aziyaka."

en: Young Compete Against Old in Hottest US Rental Market in a Decade
ny: Achinyamata Apikisana Ndi Achikulire Pamsika Wotentha Kwambiri ku US Wobwereketsa Pazaka Khumi

en: Renting an apartment can be a challenge for new college graduates who are facing the hottest U.S. rental market in a decade, along with some unexpected competition from millennials — people aged 24 to 40 — and even baby boomers — the over-57 club.
ny: Kubwereka nyumba kungakhale kovuta kwa omaliza maphunziro awo aku koleji omwe akuyang'anizana ndi msika wobwereketsa wotentha kwambiri ku US m'zaka khumi, komanso mpikisano wina wosayembekezereka wazaka chikwi - anthu azaka zapakati pa 24 mpaka 40 - komanso ngakhale ana azaka zapakati pa 57.

en: "You have aging millennials who are creating families who should be moving from rental situations into ownership but, because of the lack of housing supply, that has been stopped in a lot of instances. And so, what you see is the aging millennial population continues to rent," says Doug Ressler, manager of business intelligence at Yardi-Matrix, a commercial real estate data and research firm.
ny: "Muli ndi zaka chikwi okalamba omwe akupanga mabanja omwe akuyenera kuchoka ku malo obwereketsa kukhala umwini koma, chifukwa cha kusowa kwa nyumba, zomwe zayimitsidwa nthawi zambiri. kubwereka," atero a Doug Ressler, manejala wa intelligence yabizinesi ku Yardi-Matrix, kampani yazamalonda ndi zofufuza.

en: "It's not just about millennials, it's not just about [Gen] Z [people under 24], we also see that boomers are making a transition, he added. "Their percentage of moving into rental properties is growing in the last five years."
ny: "Sizongokhala zaka zikwizikwi, osati za [Gen] Z [anthu ochepera zaka 24], tikuwonanso kuti ma boomers akusintha, adawonjezeranso. "

en: There are a variety of reasons older people are opting for rentals, according to Ressler.
ny: Pali zifukwa zosiyanasiyana zomwe anthu okalamba amasankhira renti, malinga ndi Ressler.

en: "They've lived in a home for so long and they want to be able to reduce their expenses on a fixed income," he says. "They want to live in a social cohort, like a retirement community, and things like that where it's much more socially amenable to them."
ny: "Akhala m'nyumba kwa nthawi yayitali ndipo akufuna kuti athe kuchepetsa ndalama zomwe amapeza popeza ndalama zokhazikika," akutero. "Akufuna kukhala m'gulu la anthu ocheza nawo, monga anthu opuma pantchito, ndi zinthu ngati izi zomwe zimawasangalatsa kwambiri."

en: The asking price of apartment rentals was up 10.7% in September 2021 compared to last year at the same time, according to the National Association of Realtors (NAR).
ny: Mtengo wofunsira nyumba zobwereka unakwera 10.7% mu Seputembara 2021 poyerekeza ndi chaka chatha nthawi yomweyo, malinga ndi National Association of Realtors (NAR).

en: "It's a hot market. We have never seen this market so hot in the last decade," says Gay Cororaton, NARs senior economist and director of housing and commercial research. "The average rent growth, year-over-year, is about 3-to-5%. We're seeing 11% rent growth now, so, clearly, way above trends weve had in the past."
ny: "Ndi msika wotentha. Sitinayambe tawonapo msika uwu wotentha kwambiri m'zaka khumi zapitazi, "akutero Gay Cororaton, katswiri wa zachuma wa NARs ndi mkulu wa kafukufuku wa nyumba ndi malonda. "Kukula kwapakati pa renti, chaka ndi chaka, ndi pafupifupi 3 mpaka 5%. Tikuwona kukula kwa lendi 11% tsopano, kotero, momveka bwino, pamwamba pa zomwe takhala nazo m'mbuyomu."

en: Renters are feeling the squeeze because the COVID-19 pandemic caused supply chain issues, slowing down home building in the United States. Instead of the usual 5-to-6 month supply of available single-family homes, supply dropped below two months in January 2021. The lack of housing supply means millennials are having a harder time buying a single-family home, which has been the traditional trajectory in the past.
ny: Obwereketsa akumva kufinyidwa chifukwa mliri wa COVID-19 udayambitsa zovuta zogulitsira, ndikuchepetsa ntchito yomanga nyumba ku United States. M'malo mwa miyezi 5 mpaka 6 yopezeka ya nyumba za banja limodzi, kupezeka kwatsika pansi pa miyezi iwiri mu Januwale 2021. Kusowa kwa nyumba kumatanthauza kuti millennials akuvutika kwambiri kugula nyumba yokhala ndi banja limodzi, yomwe wakhala njira zachikhalidwe zakale.

en: "The whole building industry was beset by supply chain issues," Cororaton says. "Shipments couldn't come in, the price of lumber was rising, manufacturing slowed, workers could not come in [to work], so you have shortages of frames, appliances. So, essentially, just a short supply."
ny: "Ntchito yonse yomanga idakhudzidwa ndi zovuta zogulitsira," akutero Cororton. "Zotumiza sizikanatha kubwera, mtengo wamatabwa ukukwera, kupanga pang'onopang'ono, ogwira ntchito sakanakhoza kubwera [kuntchito], kotero muli ndi kusowa kwa mafelemu, zipangizo zamakono.

en: The housing supply got even tighter during the pandemic as more investors put their money into housing, according to Cororaton, while existing homeowners looked for second homes.
ny: Nyumba zakhala zikuchulukirachulukira panthawi ya mliri pomwe osunga ndalama ambiri amaika ndalama zawo m'nyumba, malinga ndi Cooraton, pomwe eni nyumba omwe adalipo amafunafuna nyumba zachiwiri.

en: "With the pandemic, there was also a big demand for second homes, for vacation homes. Typically, vacation homes accounted for just about 5% [of the market]," she says. "Early this summer they rose to about 8%. So again, strong demand and strong imbalance of demand and supply caused home prices to rise, made them less affordable."
ny: "Ndi mliriwu, panalinso kufunikira kwakukulu kwa nyumba zachiwiri, zanyumba zatchuthi. Nthawi zambiri, nyumba zapatchuthi zimangokhala pafupifupi 5% [ya msika]," akutero. "Kumayambiriro kwa chilimwechi adakwera kufika pafupifupi 8%. Choncho kachiwiri, kufunikira kwakukulu ndi kusalinganika kwakukulu kwa kufunikira ndi kupezeka kunachititsa kuti mitengo ya nyumba ikhale yokwera mtengo, inapangitsa kuti ikhale yotsika mtengo."

en: The hottest rental markets right now are in the West and South. More renters are moving to Dallas and Houston in Texas, followed by Atlanta, Georgia; New York; Los Angeles; Austin, Texas; Phoenix, Arizona; and Washington, D.C., according to NAR.
ny: Misika yobwereketsa yotentha kwambiri pakali pano ili Kumadzulo ndi Kumwera. Obwereketsa ena akusamukira ku Dallas ndi Houston ku Texas, ndikutsatiridwa ndi Atlanta, Georgia; New York; Los Angeles; Austin, Texas; Phoenix, Arizona; ndi Washington, DC, malinga ndi NAR.

en: Cororaton expects the coming year to be a little better but says the housing shortage is likely to continue for the next few years.
ny: Cororaton akuyembekeza kuti chaka chomwe chikubwerachi zikhala bwinoko pang'ono koma akuti kuchepa kwa nyumba kupitilira zaka zingapo zikubwerazi.

en: "You know, the old adage of moving from rentals into homeownership, that whole polemic may be changing," says Ressler. "The sweet spot was always the millennials, and now the millennials are being replaced by the [Gen] Zs, but the millennials are staying longer and the Zs are coming on board, and now you've got the demographic of the boomers … What it means is a very profitable and dynamic [rental] market that's going to continue to grow."
ny: "Mukudziwa, mwambi wakale wochoka ku renti kupita ku eni nyumba, vuto lonselo likhoza kusintha," akutero Ressler. "Malo okoma nthawi zonse anali azaka chikwi, ndipo tsopano zaka chikwi zikusinthidwa ndi [Gen] Z, koma zaka chikwi zikukhala motalikirapo ndipo ma Z akubwera, ndipo tsopano muli ndi chiwerengero cha anthu omwe akukula ... zikutanthauza kuti ndi msika wopindulitsa komanso wosinthika [wobwereketsa] womwe upitirire kukula. "

en: Are COVID-19 Restrictions Stunting Children’s Immune Systems?
ny: Kodi Zoletsa za COVID-19 Zikusokoneza Chitetezo cha Ana?

en: Some medical experts have expressed concern that COVID-19 preventative measures, like masking and remote schooling, are potentially weakening childrens immune systems by shielding them from the usual childhood illnesses.
ny: Akatswiri ena azachipatala awonetsa kuti ali ndi nkhawa kuti njira zopewera COVID-19, monga masking ndi maphunziro akutali, zitha kufooketsa chitetezo cha ana powateteza ku matenda omwe amakhalapo nthawi zonse.

en: "There are a lot of reasons to believe that kids need to be exposed to things to keep their immunity complex, so that should they encounter something very dangerous, they have aspects of their immunity that might cross over and help protect them against those things," says Sara Sawyer, a professor of molecular, cellular and developmental biology at the University of Colorado Boulder.
ny: "Pali zifukwa zambiri zokhulupirira kuti ana amafunika kuwonetseredwa ndi zinthu kuti chitetezo chawo chitetezeke, kotero kuti akakumana ndi chinthu choopsa kwambiri, ali ndi mbali zina za chitetezo chawo zomwe zingawoloke ndikuthandizira kuwateteza kuzinthu zimenezo, " akutero Sara Sawyer, pulofesa wa biology ya maselo, ma cell ndi chitukuko ku yunivesite ya Colorado Boulder.

en: At birth, vulnerable infants get antibodies from their mothers breast milk, which helps protect them until they can build their own immunity.
ny: Akabadwa, makanda omwe ali pachiwopsezo amapeza ma antibodies kuchokera ku mkaka wa amayi awo, omwe amawateteza kufikira atapanga chitetezo chawo.

en: Its no accident that babies start putting things in their mouths as soon as they gain enough dexterity to pick things up.  "They're doing that because they're sampling the environment and building their immunity. That's an evolutionary trait," Sawyer says.
ny: Sizowopsa kuti makanda amayamba kuyika zinthu mkamwa mwawo atangopeza luso lokwanira kuti atenge zinthu. "Iwo akuchita zimenezo chifukwa akuyesa chilengedwe ndikumanga chitetezo chawo. Icho ndi chikhalidwe cha chisinthiko, "akutero Sawyer.

en: "Theyre exposing their body to germs in a certain, level way to build their immunity.
ny: “Amaika matupi awo ku majeremusi m’njira yakutiyakuti, kuti atetezeke.

en: So, some people would argue that childhood illnesses, like colds and stomach bugs, build our immunity so that when more dangerous things come along, we're prepared and we don't get as sick from those more dangerous things."
ny: Chifukwa chake, anthu ena anganene kuti matenda aubwana, monga chimfine ndi nsikidzi zam'mimba, zimalimbitsa chitetezo chathu kuti zinthu zoopsa zikadzabwera, timakhala okonzeka ndipo sitidwala chifukwa cha zinthu zoopsa kwambiri. "

en: Even before the pandemic, epidemiological evidence suggested that children in more developed countries, where handwashing and the use of sanitizer are more prevalent, might have less-developed immune systems compared to kids in developing nations who are routinely exposed to more bacteria, viruses and allergens.
ny: Ngakhale mliriwu usanachitike, umboni wa miliri udawonetsa kuti ana omwe ali m'maiko otukuka kwambiri, komwe kusamba m'manja ndi kugwiritsa ntchito mankhwala oyeretsa kumapezeka kwambiri, atha kukhala ndi chitetezo chamthupi chochepa poyerekeza ndi ana a m'maiko omwe akutukuka kumene omwe nthawi zambiri amakumana ndi mabakiteriya, ma virus ndi ma allergen. .

en: This makes kids in more industrialized countries more vulnerable to developing autoimmune diseases, according to whats known as the "hygiene hypothesis."
ny: Izi zimapangitsa ana m'mayiko olemera kwambiri kukhala pachiopsezo chotenga matenda a autoimmune, malinga ndi zomwe zimatchedwa "hygiene hypothesis."

en: "The hygiene hypothesis is actually quite controversial because it's thought that our exposure to microbes isn't the only factor," says Cody Warren, a virologist and immunologist who is a postdoctoral fellow at the University of Colorado Boulder.
ny: "Lingaliro laukhondo ndilotsutsana kwambiri chifukwa amaganiza kuti kukhudzidwa kwathu ndi tizilombo toyambitsa matenda sizomwe zimachititsa," akutero Cody Warren, katswiri wa tizilombo toyambitsa matenda komanso immunologist yemwe ndi mnzake wa postdoctoral ku yunivesite ya Colorado Boulder.

en: "A lot of this could also be dictated by genetics, diet, and the environment that we live in.
ny: "Zambiri mwa izi zitha kulamulidwa ndi majini, zakudya, komanso malo omwe tikukhalamo.

en: That also shapes our immune system… it's a real multifactorial thing that we can't fully account for just by wearing masks.
ny: Izi zimapanganso chitetezo chathu chamthupi… ndizinthu zambiri zomwe sitingathe kuwerengera mokwanira povala masks.

en: There are other things that go into that equation."
ny: Pali zinthu zina zomwe zimalowa mu equation iyi. "

en: Warren, the father of three young children, says spending lots of time outdoors is one way to balance the negatives of isolation.
ny: Warren, tate wa ana aang’ono atatu, akuti kuthera nthaŵi yochuluka panja ndi njira imodzi yochepetsera kuipa kwa kudzipatula.

en: "Just exploring microbes in the environment also is benefiting [and] training our immune system," Warren says. "Our immune systems get trained through the foods that we eat, which also have microorganisms on them.
ny: "Kungoyang'ana tizilombo tating'onoting'ono m'chilengedwe kumapindulanso [ndi] kuphunzitsa chitetezo chathu cha mthupi," akutero Warren. Chitetezo chathu cha mthupi chimaphunzitsidwa kudzera muzakudya zomwe timadya, zomwe zimakhalanso ndi tizilombo toyambitsa matenda.

en: And so, despite the fact that we've kind of been hunkered down a little bit, I do feel that our immune systems will catch up."
ny: Ndipo chifukwa chake, ngakhale takhala tikuvutitsidwa pang'ono, ndikuwona kuti chitetezo chathu cha mthupi chitha. ”

en: There are other things parents can do, he says, to boost their childrens immune systems during pandemic times.  "One of the most important things you can do is just to stay up to date on vaccines.
ny: Palinso zinthu zina zomwe makolo angachite, akutero, kuti alimbikitse chitetezo cha ana awo panthawi ya mliri. "Chimodzi mwazinthu zofunika kwambiri zomwe mungachite ndikungodziwa za katemera.

en: That's one of the best ways that we have to train our immune systems," Warren says.
ny: Imeneyi ndi imodzi mwa njira zabwino kwambiri zophunzitsira chitetezo chathu cha mthupi," akutero Warren.

en: "But also, equally important is making sure our children have a good diet and they regulate stress.
ny: "Komanso, chofunikiranso ndikuwonetsetsa kuti ana athu ali ndi zakudya zabwino komanso amawongolera kupsinjika.

en: It's been well documented that both of those — having a good diet, a less stressful environment — can have a positive impact on our immune system."
ny: Zatsimikiziridwa bwino kuti zonsezi - kukhala ndi zakudya zabwino, malo osadetsa nkhawa kwambiri - zingakhale ndi zotsatira zabwino pa chitetezo chathu cha mthupi. "

en: Once public health officials say masks are no longer necessary, Sawyer thinks pointing out the positives of putting our masks away could reassure hesitant parents who worry about their children getting sick.
ny: Akuluakulu azaumoyo atanena kuti masks sakufunikanso, Sawyer akuganiza kuti kunena zabwino zoyika masks athu kumatha kutsimikizira makolo omwe akukayikakayika omwe akuda nkhawa kuti ana awo akudwala.

en: "Maybe we should have a public conversation about the possible reasons to take that mask off, if they are in school, and get back to the normal repertoire of relatively safe childhood illnesses," she says.
ny: "Mwina tiyenera kukambirana pagulu pazifukwa zomwe zingachotsere chigobachi, ngati ali kusukulu, ndi kubwereranso ku mbiri yakale ya matenda otetezeka aubwana," akutero.

en: "The plus side of childhood illnesses is that they can build up that hornet's nest of immunity that could protect kids against new things that then come along."
ny: "Chothandiza kwambiri pa matenda aubwana ndikuti amatha kupanga chisa chachitetezo chomwe chingateteze ana kuzinthu zatsopano zomwe zimabwera."

en: US Quietly Expands Asylum Limits While Preparing to End Them
ny: US Imakulitsa Mwachifatse Malire a Asylum Pamene Akukonzekera Kuwathetsa

en: The Biden administration has begun expelling Cubans and Nicaraguans to Mexico under pandemic-related powers to deny migrants a chance to seek asylum, expanding use of the rule even as it publicly says it has been trying to unwind it, officials said Wednesday.
ny: Boma la Biden layamba kuthamangitsa anthu aku Cuba ndi ku Nicaragua ku Mexico pansi pa mphamvu zokhudzana ndi mliri kuti aletse osamukira kumayiko ena mwayi wokafuna chitetezo, ndikukulitsa kugwiritsa ntchito lamuloli ngakhale anena poyera kuti akhala akuyesera kuthetsa, akuluakulu adatero Lachitatu.

en: The U.S. struck agreement with Mexico to expel up to 100 Cubans and 20 Nicaraguans a day from three locations: San Diego; El Paso, Texas; and Rio Grande Valley, Texas, according to a U.S. official with direct knowledge of the effort.
ny: A US adachita mgwirizano ndi Mexico kuti athamangitse anthu aku Cuba 100 ndi 20 Nicaragua pa tsiku kuchokera kumadera atatu: San Diego; El Paso, Texas; ndi Rio Grande Valley, Texas, malinga ndi mkulu wina wa ku United States yemwe akudziwa za kuyesayesako.

en: The expulsions began April 27 and will end May 22, the official told The Associated Press on condition of anonymity because the agreement has not been made public.
ny: Kuthamangitsidwaku kudayamba pa Epulo 27 ndipo kutha pa Meyi 22, mkuluyo adauza The Associated Press kuti asatchulidwe chifukwa mgwirizanowu sunaululidwe.

en: They are carried out under Title 42 authority, a public health law that has been used to expel migrants on grounds of preventing spread of COVID-19. Title 42 is due to expire May 23, unless a judge intervenes.
ny: Izi zikuchitika pansi pa ulamuliro wa Mutu 42, lamulo laumoyo wa anthu lomwe lakhala likugwiritsidwa ntchito kuthamangitsa osamukira kumayiko ena chifukwa chopewa kufalikira kwa COVID-19. Mutu 42 uyenera kutha pa Meyi 23, pokhapokha woweruza atalowererapo.

en: The U.S. and Mexico agreed April 26 to a very limited number of expulsions of Cubans and Nicaraguans, according to a high-level Mexican official who spoke on condition of anonymity because they were not authorized to comment publicly.
ny: US ndi Mexico adagwirizana pa Epulo 26 kuti pakhale anthu ochepa othamangitsidwa aku Cuba ndi Nicaragua, malinga ndi mkulu wina waku Mexico yemwe adalankhula mosadziwika chifukwa sanaloledwe kuyankha pagulu.

en: It was prompted by higher numbers of migrants from those two countries coming to the U.S. border.
ny: Izi zidachititsidwa ndi kuchuluka kwa anthu osamukira kumayiko awiriwa akubwera kumalire a US.

en: Mexico also took into account that the U.S. government had started processing visas in Cuba again, the official said. Mexico had also begun processing visas for Cubans.
ny: Mexico idaganiziranso kuti boma la US lidayambanso kukonza ma visa ku Cuba, mkuluyo adatero. Mexico idayambanso kukonza ma visa a anthu aku Cuba.

en: Another Mexican official, also not authorized to comment publicly, confirmed that up to 100 Cubans and 20 Nicaraguans were being expelled from San Diego under Title 42.
ny: Mkulu wina waku Mexico, yemwenso sanaloledwe kuyankha pagulu, adatsimikiza kuti mpaka 100 aku Cuba ndi 20 aku Nicaragua akuthamangitsidwa ku San Diego pansi pa Mutu 42.

en: The U.S. Department of Homeland Security did not immediately respond to a request for comment.
ny: Unduna wa Zachitetezo ku US sunayankhe mwachangu pempho loti apereke ndemanga.

en: Until last week, Mexico only agreed to take Guatemalans, Hondurans and El Salvadorans — in addition to Mexicans — under Title 42 authority. Other nationalities are subject to Title 42 but costs, strained diplomatic ties and other considerations often make it difficult to send them back to their home countries.
ny: Mpaka sabata yatha, Mexico idangovomera kutenga anthu aku Guatemalans, Honduras ndi El Salvador - kuphatikiza aku Mexico - pansi pa ulamuliro wa Mutu 42. Mayiko ena ali pansi pa Mutu 42 koma mtengo, mgwirizano waukazembe ndi malingaliro ena nthawi zambiri zimapangitsa kuti zikhale zovuta kuwatumiza kumayiko awo.

en: It's next to impossible for the U.S. to expel migrants to Cuba or Nicaragua because of poor relations with those governments. That has posed a challenge for the Biden administration as more people from those countries seek haven in the United States.
ny: Ndizosatheka kuti dziko la US lithamangitse osamukira ku Cuba kapena ku Nicaragua chifukwa chosagwirizana ndi maboma amenewo. Izi zabweretsa zovuta kwa olamulira a Biden pomwe anthu ambiri ochokera m'maikowa akufunafuna malo ku United States.

en: Cubans were stopped by U.S. authorities more than 32,000 times on the Mexican border in March, double the number in February and more than five times October's count, according to U.S. Customs and Border Protection. Nicaragua eased travel restrictions from Cuba in November, making it easier for Cubans to continue by land to the U.S. border. Most enter the U.S. in or near Yuma, Arizona, and Del Rio, Texas.
ny: Anthu aku Cuba adayimitsidwa ndi akuluakulu aku US nthawi zopitilira 32,000 pamalire a Mexico mu Marichi, kuwirikiza kawiri kuchuluka kwa February komanso kupitilira kasanu kuwerengera kwa Okutobala, malinga ndi US Customs and Border Protection. Nicaragua idachepetsa zoletsa kuyenda kuchokera ku Cuba mu Novembala, kupangitsa kuti anthu aku Cuba apitirire pamtunda kupita kumalire a US. Ambiri amalowa ku US ku Yuma, Arizona, ndi Del Rio, Texas.

en: Nicaraguans were stopped more than 16,000 times in March, more than double September's level. The vast majority enter in South Texas.
ny: Anthu aku Nicaragua adayimitsidwa nthawi zopitilira 16,000 mu Marichi, kupitilira mulingo wa Seputembala kawiri. Ambiri amapita ku South Texas.

en: Lifting Title 42 has proved controversial as midterm elections near, even for Biden's Democratic Party, amid concerns that the U.S. is unprepared for an anticipated increase in migrants seeking asylum. Authorities stopped migrants more than 221,000 times in March, the highest mark in 22 years.
ny: Lifting Title 42 zakhala zotsutsana ngati zisankho zapakati pazaka zatsala pang'ono kuyandikira, ngakhale a Biden's Democratic Party, pomwe akuda nkhawa kuti US sinakonzekere chiwonjezeko cha osamukira omwe akufunafuna chitetezo. Akuluakulu adayimitsa osamukira kumayiko opitilira 221,000 m'mwezi wa Marichi, chomwe ndi chizindikiro chachikulu kwambiri m'zaka 22.

en: The White House and Homeland Security Department have publicly stood behind the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention's decision to end the measure because it could no longer be justified on grounds of protecting public health.
ny: Dipatimenti ya White House ndi Homeland Security idayimilira poyera kumbuyo kwa Centers for Disease Control and Prevention kuti athetse vutoli chifukwa sizingakhalenso zomveka chifukwa choteteza thanzi la anthu.

en: But the practice of expelling Cubans and Nicaraguans runs counter to the administration's public statements that it was phasing out use of the pandemic powers to prepare for May 23.
ny: Koma mchitidwe wothamangitsa anthu aku Cuba ndi aku Nicaragua ukutsutsana ndi zomwe akuluakulu aboma adanena pagulu kuti akusiya kugwiritsa ntchito mphamvu za mliri kukonzekera Meyi 23.

en: The U.S. has expelled migrants more than 1.8 million times under Title 42 authority since March 2020, effectively overriding rights to seek asylum under U.S. law and international treaty. In doing so, migrants are not subject to immigration law, which include rights to seek protection from persecution at home.
ny: US yathamangitsa osamukira kumayiko opitilira 1.8 miliyoni motsogozedwa ndi Title 42 kuyambira Marichi 2020, ndikupambana ufulu wofunafuna chitetezo pansi pa malamulo aku US ndi mgwirizano wapadziko lonse lapansi. Pochita zimenezi, anthu othawa kwawo sakhala pansi pa lamulo la anthu othawa kwawo, lomwe limaphatikizapo ufulu wofunafuna chitetezo ku chizunzo kunyumba.

en: The administration said in court filings that it began processing more Central American adults under immigration laws after the CDC's announcement on April 1. But a federal judge in Louisiana ruled last week that it couldn't start unwinding Title 42 while it was still in effect.
ny: Boma linanena m'makhothi kuti lidayamba kukonza anthu akuluakulu aku Central America motsatira malamulo obwera ndi anthu osamukira kumayiko ena pambuyo pa chilengezo cha CDC pa Epulo 1. Koma woweruza wa federal ku Louisiana adagamula sabata yatha kuti sangayambe kumasula Mutu 42 udakalipo.

en: U.S. District Judge Robert Summerhays strongly criticized the CDC's decision, suggesting he would try to keep Title 42 in effect after May 23. A hearing is scheduled May 13 for oral arguments.
ny: Woweruza Wachigawo cha US a Robert Summerhays adadzudzula kwambiri chigamulo cha CDC, ponena kuti ayesa kusunga Mutu 42 kuti ugwire ntchito pambuyo pa May 23. Kumvetsera kukukonzekera Meyi 13 kuti akambirane pakamwa.

en: Marisa Limon, senior director of advocacy and planning at the Hope Border Institute, said advocates began learning about expulsions of Cubans and Nicaraguans from El Paso on Monday and later confirmed the new practice with U.S. officials.
ny: Marisa Limon, mkulu wa advocacy and planning ku Hope Border Institute, adati olimbikitsa adayamba kuphunzira za kuthamangitsidwa kwa anthu aku Cuba ndi Nicaragua ku El Paso Lolemba ndipo pambuyo pake adatsimikizira mchitidwe watsopanowu ndi akuluakulu aku US.

en: Limon said the administration is "trying to get every last bit out of Title 42" before it expires. She called it "sobering" but consistent with the administration's efforts to have other countries in the Western hemisphere take more responsibility for hosting people fleeing their homes.
ny: Limon adati oyang'anira "akuyesera kuti atulutse gawo lililonse pamutu 42" usanathe. Adazitcha "zochititsa chidwi" koma zikugwirizana ndi zomwe akuluakulu aboma akuyesetsa kuti mayiko ena aku Western hemisphere atenge udindo wochereza anthu omwe akuthawa kwawo.

en: Mexico Relocates Migrant Camp; Haitians Appear at Border
ny: Mexico Isamutsa Msasa Wosamuka; Anthu aku Haiti Akuwonekera Pamalire

en: Mexican authorities said Tuesday they have relocated a migrant camp that sprung up in a park in the border city of Reynosa, moving about 2,000 people from Central America and Haiti to a shelter in the city, across the border from McAllen, Texas.
ny: Akuluakulu aku Mexico ati Lachiwiri adasamutsa msasa wosamukira kwawo womwe unayambira paki yomwe ili m'malire a mzinda wa Reynosa, ndikusuntha anthu pafupifupi 2,000 ochokera ku Central America ndi Haiti kupita kumalo okhala mumzinda, kudutsa malire a McAllen, Texas.

en: The camp of migrants mainly from Guatemala, El Salvador, Honduras and Haiti sprung up after U.S. officials, citing the pandemic, invoked a health rule that denies migrants a chance to seek asylum.
ny: Msasa wa anthu othawa kwawo makamaka ochokera ku Guatemala, El Salvador, Honduras ndi Haiti udayamba pambuyo poti akuluakulu aku US, atatchula za mliriwu, adapempha lamulo la zaumoyo lomwe limaletsa osamukira kwawo mwayi wopeza chitetezo.

en: Mexico's National Immigration Institute said the migrants were taken around midnight Monday to the shelter, which it said will have better hygiene and food services.
ny: National Immigration Institute ku Mexico yati osamukirawo adatengedwa pakati pausiku Lolemba kupita kumalo ogona, komwe akuti azikhala ndiukhondo komanso chakudya.

en: But on Monday, people in another border city, Nuevo Laredo, said hundreds of migrants, mainly Haitians, have streamed into that city, which is across the border from Laredo, Texas
ny: Koma Lolemba, anthu akumzinda wina wakumalire, Nuevo Laredo, adati mazana ambiri othawa kwawo, makamaka aku Haiti, adakhamukira mumzindawu, womwe uli kutsidya la Laredo, Texas.

en: The rush apparently started after the U.S. began processing some asylum-seekers there.
ny: Kuthamangirako kukuwoneka kuti kudayamba pomwe US ​​idayamba kukonza anthu ena ofuna chitetezo kumeneko.

en: The Catholic bishop of Nuevo Laredo said Monday that migrant shelters there are overcrowded, with some migrants sleeping outside in tents.
ny: Bishopu wa Katolika ku Nuevo Laredo adati Lolemba kuti malo osamukirako ali odzaza, ndipo ena osamukira kumagona panja m'mahema.

en: Bishop Enrique Sánchez Martínez said migrants started streaming into Nuevo Laredo in late April, though the city isn't usually popular among migrants, in part because it is dominated by the violent Northeast drug cartel.
ny: Bishopu Enrique Sánchez Martínez adati anthu osamukira kwawo adayamba kukhamukira ku Nuevo Laredo kumapeto kwa Epulo, ngakhale mzindawu sudziwika bwino pakati pa anthu osamukira kumayiko ena, mwa zina chifukwa umakhala wotsogozedwa ndi gulu lazachiwawa lakumpoto chakum'mawa.

en: "It is new for us because this is the last place they come, due to the conditions of our border, of our city, which are sometimes adverse for migrants," the bishop said. "But since they opened the door in the United States to asylum requests, a lot of them came in large groups."
ny: "Zatsopano kwa ife chifukwa ano ndi malo omaliza omwe amabwera chifukwa cha malire athu, a mzinda wathu, zomwe nthawi zina zimakhala zovuta kwa osamukira," adatero bishopu. "Koma popeza adatsegula chitseko ku United States kuti apemphe chitetezo, ambiri a iwo anabwera m'magulu akuluakulu."

en: Marvin Ajic, the director of the Casa Nazareth shelter, said that around April 16, Mexican authorities notified the shelters that the United States would resume processing asylum claims for humanitarian reasons.
ny: Marvin Ajic, director of the Casa Nazareth shelter, adati chakumapeto kwa Epulo 16, akuluakulu aku Mexico adadziwitsa anthu omwe akukhalamo kuti United States iyambiranso kukonza zopempha zopulumutsira pazifukwa zothandiza anthu.

en: The U.S. had begun allowing more people in, especially Central American adults, to prepare for lifting Title 42 — a pandemic-era health rule that denies migrants a chance to enter the U.S. seek asylum — on May 23. But a federal judge in Louisiana ruled last week that the government could not unwind the rule before the end date.
ny: US idayamba kulola anthu ambiri, makamaka achikulire aku Central America, kukonzekera kukweza Mutu 42 - lamulo laumoyo lanthawi ya mliri lomwe limakana osamukira ku US kuti akapeze chitetezo - pa Meyi 23. Koma woweruza waboma ku Louisiana adagamula sabata yatha kuti boma silinathe kumasula lamuloli lisanafike tsiku lomaliza.

en: "The (Mexican) immigration officials organized things with the shelters, and the plan was to send people who had been waiting a long time, without any checks, basically anyone," Ajic said.
ny: "Akuluakulu olowa (ku Mexico) adakonza zinthu ndi malo okhala, ndipo cholinga chake chinali kutumiza anthu omwe akhala akudikirira kwa nthawi yayitali, opanda macheke, makamaka aliyense," adatero Ajic.

en: That apparently drew the attention of other migrants, including Haitians.
ny: Izi zikuoneka kuti zinakopa chidwi cha anthu ena othawa kwawo, kuphatikizapo a ku Haiti.

en: In September, similar rumors sparked a rush by about 15,000 mostly Haitian refugees to the Texas border, where they camped under a bridge. U.S. officials began large scale deportations of Haitians while also allowing thousands to remain in the U.S.
ny: M’mwezi wa September, mphekesera zofanana ndi zimenezi zinachititsa kuti anthu pafupifupi 15,000 ambiri a ku Haiti athamangire kumalire a Texas, kumene anamanga misasa pansi pa mlatho. Akuluakulu aku US adayamba kuthamangitsidwa kwa anthu aku Haiti kwinaku akulola kuti masauzande ambiri akhalebe ku US

en: Ajic warned migrants against coming to the border, noting the risks. On Monday, Mexico's National Immigration Institute said that so far this year, it has pulled the bodies of 19 immigrants from the Rio Grande, also known as the Rio Bravo.
ny: Ajic anachenjeza osamuka kuti asabwere kumalire, ndikuwona zoopsa. Lolemba, National Immigration Institute ku Mexico idati mpaka pano chaka chino, yatulutsa matupi a anthu 19 ochokera ku Rio Grande, yomwe imadziwikanso kuti Rio Bravo.

en: New US Rule Grants Automatic Work Permit Extensions to Noncitizens
ny: Ulamuliro Watsopano waku US Umapereka Zilolezo Zogwiritsa Ntchito Mwadzidzidzi Kuwonjezedwa kwa Anthu Osakhala

en: U.S. Citizenship and Immigration Services (USCIS) announced Tuesday that it would automatically extend for 360 days the work permits of immigrants who applied to renew their work authorization amid the current backlog in processing times.
ny: US Citizenship and Immigration Services (USCIS) yalengeza Lachiwiri kuti ingowonjezera kwa masiku 360 zilolezo zogwirira ntchito za anthu osamukira kumayiko ena omwe apempha kuti akonzenso chilolezo chawo pantchito mkati mwazovuta zomwe zikuchitika.

en: The new notice expands on the 180-day extension USCIS announced in November. It is expected to prevent about 260,000 immigrants from losing their work permits in the next 18 months. It will also give the agency extra time to clear applicants waiting in line, the agency said in a statement.
ny: Chidziwitso chatsopanochi chikukulirakulira pakukulitsa kwa masiku 180 USCIS yolengezedwa mu Novembala. Akuyembekezeka kuletsa anthu pafupifupi 260,000 obwera kumayiko ena kuti asatayike zilolezo zawo m'miyezi 18 ikubwerayi. Zidzapatsanso bungweli nthawi yowonjezera kuti lichotse omwe akudikirira pamzere, bungweli lidatero.

en: "This temporary rule will provide those noncitizens otherwise eligible for the automatic extension an opportunity to maintain employment and provide critical support for their families while avoiding further disruption for U.S. employers," USCIS Director Ur M. Jaddou said in a statement.
ny: "Lamulo losakhalitsali lidzapatsa anthu omwe sali oyenerera kuti awonjezere mwayi woti apitirize ntchito komanso kupereka chithandizo chofunikira kwa mabanja awo ndikupewa kusokoneza ena olemba ntchito ku US," adatero mkulu wa USCIS Ur M. Jaddou m'mawu ake.

en: The extension, which takes effect Wednesday, aims to stabilize operations for U.S. employers and help people with pending employment authorizations who have a job and are working in the U.S.
ny: Zowonjezera, zomwe ziyamba kugwira ntchito Lachitatu, cholinga chake ndi kukhazikitsa bata kwa olemba ntchito aku US ndikuthandizira anthu omwe ali ndi chilolezo choyembekezera ntchito omwe ali ndi ntchito ndipo akugwira ntchito ku US.

en: USCIS is the agency in charge of handling the nation's immigration paperwork. In recent years, it has struggled with backlogs, an issue made worse by the COVID-19 pandemic and budget shortfalls.
ny: USCIS ndi bungwe lomwe limayang'anira ntchito zolembera anthu olowa m'dzikolo. M'zaka zaposachedwa, yakhala ikulimbana ndi zotsalira, vuto lomwe likukulirakulira chifukwa cha mliri wa COVID-19 komanso kuchepa kwa bajeti.

en: In April, Jaddou told U.S. government officials during a congressional hearing that USCIS had 8.5 million pending immigration cases, including those seeking green cards and U.S. naturalization.
ny: M'mwezi wa Epulo, a Jaddou adauza akuluakulu aboma la US pamsonkhano wamsonkhano kuti USCIS ili ndi milandu 8.5 miliyoni yomwe ikuyembekezera kusamukira, kuphatikiza omwe akufuna makhadi obiriwira komanso chibadwa cha US.

en: She said more than half of those pending cases were taking longer than the agency's normal processing times.
ny: Anati opitilira theka la milandu yomwe ikuyembekezerayi ikutenga nthawi yayitali kuposa nthawi yomwe bungweli limakonza.

en: Asylum-seekers, immigrants adjusting their status to permanent residence and other noncitizens going through the U.S. immigration process are among the noncitizens affected by the latest work authorization extension.
ny: Ofunafuna malo opulumukirako, olowa m'mayiko ena omwe akusintha malo awo kukhala okhazikika komanso anthu ena osakhala nzika zomwe zikuyenda munjira yosamukira ku US ndi ena mwa anthu omwe si nzika zomwe zakhudzidwa ndi kuwonjezereka kwaposachedwa kwachilolezo cha ntchito.

en: The agency had reported that processing times for asylum applicants looking to renew work permits increased from seven months in 2017 to 11 months in 2021.
ny: Bungweli lidanenanso kuti nthawi zogwirira ntchito kwa omwe akufunsira kuthawa kwawo omwe akufuna kukonzanso zilolezo zakwera kuchoka pa miyezi isanu ndi iwiri mu 2017 mpaka miyezi 11 mu 2021.

en: In March, USCIS announced a program to reduce backlogs, including the expansion of premium processing for certain applications where applicants could pay a higher fee to expedite paperwork processing.
ny: M'mwezi wa Marichi, USCIS idalengeza za pulogalamu yochepetsera zotsalira, kuphatikiza kukulitsidwa kwa ma premium a mapulogalamu ena pomwe olembetsa atha kulipira ndalama zambiri kuti afulumizitse kukonza mapepala.

en: According to the USCIS, most of the announced changes simply restore options offered before the Trump administration's slowdown of USCIS processing and before the COVID-19 pandemic further slowed the agency's resources.
ny: Malinga ndi USCIS, zosintha zambiri zomwe zalengezedwa zimangobwezeretsa zosankha zomwe bungwe la Trump lidapereka lisanachepetse kukonza kwa USCIS komanso mliri wa COVID-19 usanachedwetsenso chuma cha bungweli.

en: "For several years, USCIS has been in a precarious financial situation that has impaired the efficient completion of caseloads. The COVID-19 pandemic exacerbated these challenges in 2020, in addition to a hiring freeze and furlough threat leading to workforce attrition and severely reduced capacity. In 2021, before USCIS could recover from these fiscal and operational impacts, there was a sudden and dramatic increase in EAD (Employment Authorization Document) initial and renewal filings," according to the USCIS statement.
ny: "Kwa zaka zingapo, USCIS yakhala muvuto lalikulu lazachuma lomwe lalepheretsa kumaliza ntchito zochulukirachulukira. Mliri wa COVID-19 udakulitsa zovuta izi mu 2020, kuphatikiza pakuyimitsidwa kwa ganyu ndikuwopseza kwanthawi yayitali komwe kumapangitsa kuti anthu azigwira ntchito movutikira komanso kuchepa kwambiri kwa ntchito. . Mu 2021, USCIS isanayambirenso kuwononga ndalama komanso magwiridwe antchito, panali chiwonjezeko chadzidzidzi komanso chochititsa chidwi cha EAD (Employment Authorization Document) zolemba zoyamba ndi kukonzanso," malinga ndi mawu a USCIS.

en: The USCIS historically has been underfunded because most of the agency's funding comes from application fees that have stalled at $5 billion a year since 2019.
ny: USCIS m'mbiri yakhala ikulandila ndalama zochepa chifukwa ndalama zambiri zabungweli zimachokera ku chindapusa chomwe chayimilira $5 biliyoni pachaka kuyambira 2019.

en: What Is the US-Launched 'Uniting for Ukraine' Program?
ny: Kodi Pulogalamu ya 'Uniting for Ukraine' Yoyambitsidwa ndi US ndi Chiyani?

en: U.S. President Joe Biden recently announced the Uniting for Ukraine program, which aims to streamline the process for Ukrainians who have fled their country and are seeking safety in the United States.
ny: Purezidenti wa US a Joe Biden posachedwapa adalengeza pulogalamu ya Uniting for Ukraine, yomwe cholinga chake ndi kukonza ndondomeko ya anthu aku Ukraine omwe athawa m'dziko lawo ndipo akufuna chitetezo ku United States.

en: The new program, which took effect Monday, will complement existing legal pathways available to those fleeing Russian aggression due to the ongoing Russia-Ukraine crisis, Biden administration officials said.
ny: Pulogalamu yatsopanoyi, yomwe idayamba Lolemba, ikwaniritsa njira zomwe zilipo kwa omwe akuthawa ziwawa zaku Russia chifukwa chazovuta zomwe zikuchitika ku Russia-Ukraine, akuluakulu aboma a Biden adatero.

en: "The U.S. Department of Homeland Security (DHS) will continue to provide relief to the Ukrainian people, while supporting our European allies who have shouldered so much as the result of Russia's brutal invasion of Ukraine," Secretary of Homeland Security Alejandro Mayorkas said in a statement to reporters on April 21.
ny: "Dipatimenti ya US Homeland Security (DHS) ipitiliza kupereka mpumulo kwa anthu aku Ukraine, kwinaku akuthandizira ogwirizana athu aku Europe omwe achitapo kanthu chifukwa cha kuukira kwankhanza kwa Russia ku Ukraine," Secretary of Homeland Security Alejandro Mayorkas adatero. mawu kwa atolankhani pa Epulo 21.

en: What is Uniting for Ukraine?
ny: Kodi Kugwirizana ku Ukraine ndi chiyani?

en: The program allows U.S. citizens and residents to sponsor Ukrainian refugees under different immigration statuses. The online portal, open to potential sponsors or organizations, is accepting applications and has received more than 4,000 requests so far, CNN reported.
ny: Pulogalamuyi imalola nzika zaku US ndi okhalamo kuti azithandizira othawa kwawo aku Ukraine mosiyanasiyana. Tsamba lapaintaneti, lotseguka kwa omwe angakhale othandizira kapena mabungwe, likuvomera zofunsira ndipo lalandila zopempha zopitilira 4,000 mpaka pano, CNN idatero.

en: Who qualifies under the program?  Ukrainians, or an immediate family member of a Ukrainian citizen. They must have a U.S. sponsor and have been a resident of Ukraine as of February 11.
ny: Ndani ali woyenera pansi pa pulogalamuyi? Ukrainians, kapena wachibale wachibale wa nzika yaku Ukraine. Ayenera kukhala ndi othandizira aku US ndipo akhala aku Ukraine kuyambira pa February 11.

en: What are the requirements?   They must pass security checks — including a fingerprint and an FBI name check and biographic and biometric screening — and meet public health requirements, such as having the proper vaccinations, before entering the U.S.
ny: Kodi zofunika ndi ziti? Ayenera kudutsa cheke chachitetezo - kuphatikiza chala ndi cheke cha dzina la FBI ndikuwunika kwa biometric ndi biometric - ndikukwaniritsa zofunikira pazaumoyo wa anthu, monga kukhala ndi katemera woyenera, asanalowe ku US.

en: Those approved will be allowed to travel to the U.S., be considered for humanitarian parole on a case-by-case basis, stay in the country for two years, and apply for work permits.
ny: Ovomerezeka adzaloledwa kupita ku US, kuganiziridwa kuti athandizidwe pazochitika zilizonse, kukhala mdziko muno kwa zaka ziwiri, ndikufunsira zilolezo zogwirira ntchito.

en: "The United States strongly encourages Ukrainians seeking refuge in the United States who do not have and are not eligible for a visa to seek entry via Uniting for Ukraine from Europe. This will be the safest and most efficient way to pursue temporary refuge in the United States," a DHS statement said.
ny: "United States ikulimbikitsa kwambiri anthu aku Ukraine omwe akufuna chitetezo ku United States omwe alibe ndipo sakuyenera kulandira visa kuti alowe kudzera ku Uniting ku Ukraine kuchokera ku Ulaya. Iyi idzakhala njira yotetezeka komanso yothandiza kwambiri yothawirako kwakanthawi ku United States. States, "adatero DHS.

en: Who qualifies as a sponsor?
ny: Ndani ali woyenerera kukhala wothandizira?

en: U.S. citizens and other residents who hold lawful status in the United States or who are beneficiaries of Deferred Enforced Departure, Temporary Protected Status, or Deferred Action, among others.
ny: Nzika zaku US ndi ena okhala ku United States omwe ali ndi udindo wovomerezeka ku United States kapena omwe apindule ndi Deferred Enforced Departure, Temporary Protected Status, kapena Deferred Action, pakati pa ena.

en: Sponsors will be required to prove they can financially support the refugee while they are in the U.S. They also need to pass security and background vetting "to protect against exploitation and abuse." The Ukrainian applicant will receive authorization only after everything is verified, including that the sponsor has the means to support them while they are in the U.S.
ny: Othandizira adzafunika kutsimikizira kuti atha kuthandiza othawa kwawo pazachuma pamene ali ku US Ayeneranso kupititsa chitetezo ndi kuwunikira kumbuyo "kuteteza ku nkhanza ndi kuzunzidwa." Wopempha ku Ukraine adzalandira chilolezo pokhapokha zonse zitatsimikiziridwa, kuphatikizapo kuti wothandizira ali ndi njira zothandizira pamene ali ku US.

en: Who is not eligible for parole under the program?
ny: Ndani sakuyenera kulandira parole pansi pa pulogalamuyi?

en: Ukrainian citizens already in the U.S. are not eligible for parole under Uniting for Ukraine.
ny: Nzika zaku Ukraine zomwe zili kale ku US siziyenera kulandira parole pansi pa Uniting for Ukraine.

en: However, they can apply for Temporary Protected Status, which is another form of humanitarian relief that allows people to legally stay and work in the U.S.
ny: Komabe, atha kulembetsa ku Temporary Protected Status, yomwe ndi njira ina yothandizira anthu yomwe imalola anthu kukhala mwalamulo ndikugwira ntchito ku US.

en: What about those arriving at the U.S.-Mexico border?
ny: Nanga bwanji amene akufika kumalire a US-Mexico?

en: Citing safety issues, U.S. officials have urged Ukrainians not to travel to Mexico in hopes of entering the United States. In addition, U.S. Customs and Border Protection has no place to hold them while they go through the Uniting for Ukraine vetting process.
ny: Potchula zachitetezo, akuluakulu aku US alimbikitsa anthu aku Ukraine kuti asapite ku Mexico ndi chiyembekezo cholowa ku United States. Kuphatikiza apo, US Customs and Border Protection ilibe powasunga pamene akudutsa mu Uniting for Ukraine vetting process.

en: Since Uniting for Ukraine's launch on Monday, Ukrainians who arrive at U.S. ports of entry without a valid visa or without preauthorization to travel to the United States through the Uniting for Ukraine program will be denied entry and told to apply to the program.
ny: Chiyambireni kukhazikitsidwa kwa Ukraine Lolemba, anthu aku Ukraine omwe amafika ku madoko aku US opanda visa kapena popanda chilolezo chopita ku United States kudzera mu pulogalamu ya Uniting for Ukraine adzakanidwa kulowa ndikuuzidwa kuti alembetse pulogalamuyi.

en: Biden officials hope this will curb the number of Ukrainian migrants seeking humanitarian parole along the border.
ny: Akuluakulu a Biden akuyembekeza kuti izi zichepetsa kuchuluka kwa anthu osamukira ku Ukraine omwe akufunafuna ufulu wothandiza anthu kumalire.

en: Those at the border must apply under the rules of Uniting for Ukraine, meaning they must have a qualifying sponsor or a non-government agency willing to sponsor them in the U.S. for up to two years. And they need to have all required vaccinations and pass background checks.
ny: Amene ali kumalire ayenera kugwiritsa ntchito malamulo a Uniting for Ukraine, kutanthauza kuti ayenera kukhala ndi wothandizira oyenerera kapena bungwe lomwe si la boma lomwe likufuna kuwathandizira ku US kwa zaka ziwiri. Ndipo amayenera kulandira katemera wofunikira ndikuwunikanso zakumbuyo.

en: The Biden administration announced the private sponsorship initiative as another way the U.S. hopes to achieve President Biden's commitment to welcome up to 100,000 Ukrainians displaced by the Russian military invasion.
ny: Boma la Biden lidalengeza za njira yothandizira payekha ngati njira ina yomwe US ​​​​ikuyembekeza kukwaniritsa zomwe Purezidenti Biden adalonjeza kuti alandire anthu aku Ukraine okwana 100,000 omwe adasamutsidwa ndi gulu lankhondo laku Russia.

en: As of Thursday, almost 5.4 million refugees have since left Ukraine, according to U.N. data.
ny: Pofika Lachinayi, othawa kwawo pafupifupi 5.4 miliyoni achoka ku Ukraine, malinga ndi deta ya UN.

en: Report: Rwanda Should Ease Restrictions On 2003 National Elections - 2001-10-15
ny: Report: Rwanda Iyenera Kuchepetsa Zoletsa Pa zisankho za 2003 - 2001-10-15

en: In 2003 Rwanda will hold its first national elections since the 1994 genocide. A new report says the government of Rwanda needs to relax its control over public life if the polls are to have any credibility.
ny: Mu 2003 Rwanda idzachita zisankho zake zoyamba kuyambira 1994. Lipoti latsopano lati boma la Rwanda likuyenera kusiya kuwongolera moyo wa anthu ngati zisankho zikuyenera kukhala zodalirika.

en: There was relief when the Rwandan Patriotic Front seized power in Rwanda in 1994, ending the genocide in which about 800,000 minority Tutsis and moderate Hutus were killed.
ny: Panali mpumulo pamene gulu lankhondo la Rwandan Patriotic Front linalanda ulamuliro ku Rwanda mu 1994, n’kuthetsa kuphana kumene anthu pafupifupi 800,000 a fuko la Tutsi ndi Ahutu apakati anaphedwa.

en: The new military government promised to restore democracy to Rwanda via elections in 2003.
ny: Boma latsopano lankhondo lidalonjeza kubwezeretsa demokalase ku Rwanda kudzera mu zisankho za 2003.

en: That process began in March this year, with district elections.
ny: Ndondomekoyi idayamba mu Marichi chaka chino, ndi zisankho za maboma.

en: Senior analyst Francois Grignon, of the International Crisis Group, a Brussels-based policy research organization, says he was disappointed with the district poll. Mr. Grignon says the process was so tightly controlled that he maintains no genuine opposition candidates were allowed to stand.
ny: Katswiri wamkulu, Francois Grignon, wa International Crisis Group, bungwe lofufuza za mfundo za Brussels ku Brussels, akuti adakhumudwa ndi kafukufuku wachigawo. Bambo Grignon akuti ndondomekoyi idayendetsedwa mwamphamvu kwambiri kotero kuti amasunga kuti palibe ofuna kutsutsa enieni omwe adaloledwa kuyima.

en: "There was a screening and there was a preparation of the elections, which did not allow other candidates than those who had been rubber-stamped by the government to actually contest, especially for the executive positions within the local authorities," he says. "If consensual democracy means that the political debate is actually handled before the electoral contest in such a way that it does not lead to a real competition then there is no democracy at all."
ny: “Kunali kuwunika komanso kukonzekera zisankho, zomwe sizidalole kuti anthu ena omwe adadindidwa ndi boma achite nawo mpikisano, makamaka pa maudindo akuluakulu m’maboma,” adatero. "Ngati demokalase yogwirizana ikutanthauza kuti mkangano wa ndale umayendetsedwadi musanayambe mpikisano wa zisankho m'njira yoti zisabweretse mpikisano weniweni ndiye kuti palibe demokalase nkomwe."

en: In a new report, titled Consensual Democracy in Post Genocide Rwanda, the International Crisis Group urges the international community to pressure Rwanda's government to liberalize political activity.
ny: Mu lipoti latsopano, lotchedwa Consensual Democracy in Post Genocide Rwanda, bungwe la International Crisis Group likulimbikitsa mayiko kuti azikakamiza boma la Rwanda kuti lilole kumasula ndale.

en: The report notes that the military dominates public life and there is little open criticism of the government, either in the media or by opposition figures. The Rwanda government argues that allowing a range of opinions would be dangerous in a country struggling to come to terms with its bloody past.
ny: Lipotilo likunena kuti gulu lankhondo limayang'anira miyoyo ya anthu onse ndipo palibe kutsutsa kowonekera kwa boma, kaya pawailesi yakanema kapena otsutsa. Boma la Rwanda likunena kuti kulola malingaliro osiyanasiyana kungakhale kowopsa m'dziko lomwe likuvutikira kuti ligwirizane ndi zomwe zidachitika kale.

en: But Mr. Grignon says dissent is simply being driven underground or outside Rwanda's borders.
ny: Koma a Grignon ati kusagwirizana kukungoyendetsedwa mobisa kapena kunja kwa malire a Rwanda.

en: "Opponents to the regime have to flee the country or to join in rebel movements outside the country or in the Congo and no chance to express a different view," he says. "All the good policies that the government has been implementing - including the organization of the elections, national elections, presidential and parliamentary, in 2003 - will lack the credibility because they were not implemented in an environment that actually allowed a fair contest to take place," he says.
ny: "Otsutsa boma amayenera kuthawa m'dzikolo kapena kulowa nawo zigawenga kunja kwa dziko kapena ku Congo ndipo alibe mwayi wofotokozera maganizo osiyana," akutero. “Njira zabwino zonse zomwe boma lakhala likukhazikitsa – kuphatikizapo kayendetsedwe ka zisankho, zisankho za dziko lonse, pulezidenti ndi aphungu aphungu m’chaka cha 2003 – sizidzakhala zodalirika chifukwa sizidakhazikitsidwe m’malo omwe amalola kuti mpikisano wachilungamo uchitike. ,” akutero.

en: Mr. Grignon says greater freedom of expression would strengthen Rwanda's reconciliation process and enhance its chances of a peaceful future.
ny: A Grignon ati ufulu wochuluka wolankhula ukhoza kulimbikitsa mgwirizano wa Rwanda ndikuwonjezera mwayi wake wokhala ndi tsogolo lamtendere.

en: He says the international community's involvement in reconstruction projects gives it the leverage to make this plain to the Rwandan government.
ny: Iye wati kukhudzidwa kwa mayiko pa ntchito zomanganso kumapereka mwayi woti izi zimveke bwino ku boma la Rwanda.

en: Rwanda Welcomes the Arrest of Former Rebel Leader
ny: Rwanda Yalandila Kumangidwa kwa Mtsogoleri wakale wa zigawenga

en: Rwandas Justice Minister said his government is pleased with the arrest Monday of a former rebel leader accused of masterminding genocide and violating human rights against Rwandans and Congolese villagers in 1994.
ny: Nduna ya Chilungamo ku Rwanda yati boma lake ndi lokondwa ndi kumangidwa kwa mtsogoleri wakale wa zigawenga Lolemba yemwe akuimbidwa mlandu wotsogolera kupha anthu komanso kuphwanya ufulu wachibadwidwe kwa anthu aku Rwanda ndi akumidzi yaku Congo mu 1994.

en: French authorities arrested Callixte Mbarushimana, a former leader of the infamous Democratic Forces for the Liberation of Rwanda (FDLR), an ethnic Hutu rebel group.
ny: Akuluakulu a boma ku France adamanga a Callixte Mbarushimana, mtsogoleri wakale wa gulu lodziwika bwino la Democratic Forces for the Liberation of Rwanda (FDLR), gulu la zigawenga zachihutu.

en: Tharcisse Karugarama welcomed the decision of French authorities to enforce the international arrest warrant issued by his government and the International Criminal Court (ICC) against the former rebel leader.
ny: A Tharcisse Karugarama alandila chigamulo cha akuluakulu a boma ku France kuti akhazikitse chikalata chomangidwa ndi boma lake komanso International Criminal Court (ICC) motsutsana ndi mtsogoleri wakale wa zigawenga.

en: "It is good news that Callixte Mbarushimana has been (arrested) by the French judicial authority. Good news in the sense that, first, there was an international arrest warrant against him issued by the Rwandan government in respect of (the alleged) act of genocide committed in Rwanda in 1994."
ny: "Ndi nkhani yabwino kuti Callixte Mbarushimana (amangidwa) ndi akuluakulu amilandu a ku France. Nkhani yabwino yakuti, poyamba, panali chikalata chomumanga padziko lonse lapansi chomwe chinaperekedwa ndi boma la Rwanda ponena za (zomwe) Kupha anthu ku Rwanda mu 1994."

en: Karugarama said the Hague-based court sought the arrest of the former rebel leader who was believed to be hiding in France.
ny: Karugarama wati bwalo lamilandu ku Hague likufuna kuti mtsogoleri wakale wa zigawenga amangidwe yemwe akumuganizira kuti amabisala ku France.

en: Genocide memorial in Rwanda
ny: Chikumbutso cha Genocide ku Rwanda

en: "The International Criminal Court (ICC) conducted its own investigation about his other activities and they found sufficient evidence to support the charge of war crimes and crimes against humanity perpetrated in the DRC and they issued an arrest warrant, which the French judicial authorities have executed."
ny: "Khothi la International Criminal Court (ICC) lidachita kafukufuku wake pazantchito zake zina ndipo lidapeza umboni wokwanira wotsimikizira milandu yankhondo komanso milandu yolimbana ndi anthu ku DRC ndipo idapereka chikalata chomangidwa, chomwe akuluakulu amilandu ku France adapereka. ."

en: The Hague-based court accused Mbarushimana and other rebels in the FDLR of using violence against unarmed civilians as their main tool in a campaign to forcefully obtain political power for the rebel group.
ny: Bwalo lamilandu ku Hague ladzudzula Mbarushimana ndi zigawenga zina za FDLR chifukwa chogwiritsa ntchito ziwawa anthu wamba omwe alibe zida ngati chida chawo chachikulu pa kampeni yopezera mphamvu zandale ku gulu la zigawenga.

en: According to the ICC, "as a result of this deadly blackmail (by the FDLR rebels), victims were killed, raped, and forcibly displaced, and entire villages were razed to the ground."
ny: Malinga ndi bungwe la ICC, "chifukwa cha nkhanza zakuphazi (za zigawenga za FDLR), ozunzidwa anaphedwa, kugwiriridwa, ndi kuwakakamiza kuti asamuke, ndipo midzi yonse inaphwanyidwa."
